citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
In the petting zoo area there were two juvenile pot-bellied pigs that were very itchy. The black and white pig had scaly
ears and had hair loss on the neck, legs and rib cage. There was an open sore about 2 inches by 1 inch behind the right
elbow. The facility reported that they had noticed the problem. The veterinarian had not yet been consulted by the facility.
Not seeking timely veterinary care for illness, disease, and injury can delay treatment and prolong suffering. Conditions
can continue to deteriorate without veterinary intervention.
Daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being; Provided, however, That daily observation of
animals may be accomplished by someone other than the attending veterinarian; and Provided, further, That a
mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of
animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian.
A complete routine inspection was conducted on 05 November 2024. This inspection is limited to the direct
noncompliance identified during that inspection. An additional inspection report will be delivered with the other issues
identified during this inspection. This inspection and exit interview was conducted with facility representatives. The exit
briefing was conducted 05 November 2024.
Additional Inspectors:
CARRIE BONGARD, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
In the petting zoo area there were two juvenile pot-bellied pigs that were very itchy. The black and white pig had scaly 
ears and had hair loss on the neck, legs and rib cage. There was an open sore about 2 inches by 1 inch behind the right 
elbow. The facility reported that they had noticed the problem. The veterinarian had not yet been consulted by the facility.  
Not seeking timely veterinary care for illness, disease, and injury can delay treatment and prolong suffering. Conditions 
can continue to deteriorate without veterinary intervention.  
Daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being; Provided, however, That daily observation of 
animals may be accomplished by someone other than the attending veterinarian; and Provided, further, That a 
mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of 
animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. 
 
A complete routine inspection was conducted on 05 November 2024. This inspection is limited to the direct 
noncompliance identified during that inspection. An additional inspection report will be delivered with the other issues 
identified during this inspection. This inspection and exit interview was conducted with facility representatives. The exit 
briefing was conducted 05 November 2024. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
CARRIE BONGARD, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
